placesVisited: Singapore, Malacca, Kuala Lumpur, Batu Caves, homestay at Chenderoh Lake, Cameron Highlands, Penang, Langkawi Island
generalInfo:
Combine one of the world’s greatest cities with neighbouring Malaysia on this journey up the Malay Peninsula. Starting in Singapore, you’ll head up to Malacca and Kuala Lumpur and then into the tea plantations of the Cameron Highlands, ending up on Langkawi Island where you can relax on a tropical beach.

You’ll visit two capitals on this trip: first Singapore, with its dizzying number of districts and fantastic food – a Singapore Sling is in order. Then on to Kuala Lumpur, where you can explore via its temples, skyscrapers and sky bars. Alongside these glittering metropolises, it might be the smaller cities that get your attention – like historic Georgetown in Penang and the port city of Malacca where you can take an evening river cruise.

A highlight on this trip will be the food. Singapore is amazing for the variety of food served in different districts, from Little India to Chinatown. Once you’re in Malaysia, it’s time to sample sambals and there’s a chance to try authentic dishes with your host at a homestay near Perak.

This trip ends with a few days to relax in Langkawi on the beach – where you can lie around and perhaps finally get around to editing those hundreds of food photos you’ve snapped.

dayInfo.title: Join trip in Singapore
dayInfo.description: : Arrive in Singapore, Southeast Asia's financial powerhouse and famously its cleanest, greenest city. Located just one degree north of the equator and surrounded by rainforest, modern-day Singapore is uniquely positioned to understand its own impact on the environment and has been working hard to earn its reputation as the 'Garden City'. The concrete fronts of skyscrapers and buildings are being repurposed to accommodate green spaces wherever possible, creating their own colourful ecosystems in the sky. Although it's one of the most densely populated countries on the planet, over 50% of Singapore is made up of parks and gardens, including the famous Gardens by the Bay. For those arriving on time, our tour leader will meet you in the hotel reception at 6pm for a welcome meeting. If you'd like an airport transfer today, you'll need to arrive into Singapore Changi Airport (SIN), which is a one-hour drive from the hotel. If you miss the welcome meeting, our tour leader will inform you of any essential information over breakfast on day 2. If you'd like to experience more of Singapore at your own pace or simply beat your jetlag, you can add extra nights onto your tour. Please contact us to book additional accommodation. After the welcome meeting, our tour leader will take us on a night-walking tour to get a taste of Singapore's mouth-watering street food. We'll hop on a public bus and make our way towards Chinatown, first stopping at the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple. Bathed in the twinkling glow of the city's evening lights, this is where local Singaporeans come to wind down after a busy day - you're sure to spot experts playing Chinese Chess. We then move on to Lau Pa Sat, the famous hawkers centre with its mind-boggling array of stalls. Offering everything from steaming Singapore noodles and Malaysian Laksa to Shanghai pork buns or thunder tea rice, it's the place to get adventurous with food. Our tour leader will talk us through a variety of dishes, and we'll end the night with a cooling treat such as mango shaved ice or a durian dessert.

dayInfo.title: Explore Singapore's Marina, Chinatown and Little India. Optional river cruise
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll head off on foot to discover more of this eclectic city. We'll start in the characterful commune of Little India, which grew from an Indian enclave in the 19th Century to the buzzing community we find today; brimming with restaurants, shops and art galleries all steeped in Tamil culture. We next move onto Kampong Glam, where the towering golden dome of the Sultan's Mosque watches over the narrow lanes of the Malay quarter, filled with boutique shops selling homemade wares and quirky street art galleries. We change environment again as we move into the Civic District, the birthplace of modern-day Singapore. It was from here where Sir Stamford Raffles' vision of Singapore poured outwards, and befittingly it houses some well-preserved colonial-era buildings, such as the old Parliament House, the Supreme Court building and the iconic Cricket Club. Moving into the more modern areas of Singapore, we stop off at the home of the Merlion, a mythical creature that's half-lion, half-fish, depicted here as a statue spouting water into the Singapore River below. Merlion Park offers great views of the glittering Marina Bay as a backdrop to this famous statue. We end our walking tour today at the Boat Quay, the perfect water-side spot to enjoy a bite to eat or a Singapore Sling at one of the alfresco bars or restaurants. The rest of the day is free to relax or explore at your own pace. Those interested in shopping might like to visit the trendy Orchard Street while art and nature lovers may wish to stroll around the Gardens by the Bay. It's also possible to organise a river cruise to see the city from a different perspective.

dayInfo.title: Visit Peranakan museum and Katong and Joo Chiat district. Free afternoon in Singapore
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll begin our day with a visit to the Peranakan Museum, a beautifully curated space that celebrates the unique heritage of the Peranakan, or Straits Chinese, community descendants of Chinese immigrants who settled in the Malay Archipelago and intermarried with local Malays. The museum showcases an exquisite collection of artifacts, from intricately embroidered kebayas and delicate beaded slippers to ornate wedding costumes, fine porcelain, and ancestral jewellery. Through its interactive exhibits and stories, the museum offers deep insight into the fusion of Chinese, Malay, and European influences that define Peranakan culture, revealing how this vibrant community shaped Singapore's social, culinary, and artistic landscape. To follow, we will visit the lively enclaves of Katong and Joo Chiat, which highlight the rich and baroque architecture of the Peranakan - traditional shophouses with colourful façades, ornate tiles, and decorative wooden shutters dating from the 1920s and 1930s. We will end the tour with a food tasting of Nonya popiah, a traditional, fresh Peranakan-style spring roll filled with finely shredded jicama (bangkuang), vegetables like carrots and bean sprouts, Chinese sausage, and sometimes prawns or crab meat, all wrapped in a thin, soft egg-based wheat flour crepe. The dish offers a complex sweet, savoury, and tangy flavour profile from a rich, flavourful braised filling and is served with accompaniments like sweet sauce, chili, garlic paste, and crushed peanuts. The rest of the afternoon is free for you to explore further. You can visit the impressive Gardens by the Bay, which displays vibrant plants and blooms, and the iconic Supertree Grove, or head to the famous Marina Bay Sands Sky Park and rooftop bar for a drink.

dayInfo.title: Cross the border into Malaysia and drive to Malacca. Evening river cruise
dayInfo.description: : Leaving Singapore behind this morning, we cross at the Woodlands checkpoint onto the Johor Causeway bridge into Malaysia. We drive north, reaching the Dutch colonial settlement of Malacca in around four hours. Malacca is one of the oldest towns in Malaysia, and certainly the most cosmopolitan. In its time it has been ruled by the Portuguese, the Dutch, the British and the Japanese, finally becoming Malay in 1957. This afternoon we make a visit to Villa Sentosa. This traditional house offers an interesting insight into the daily lives of a typical middle-class Malaysian family at the turn of the 20th century. This house-come-museum has been kept almost entirely as it was 100 years ago and is located within the sleepy settlement of Kampong Morten, a village community hidden within the confines of the city. This evening, we include a river cruise - a great way to experience Malacca's buzz from a different perspective.

dayInfo.title: Walking tour of the old town and visit to Villa Sentosa. Then drive to Kuala Lumpur
dayInfo.description: : Old Malacca is a fascinating area to wander around and discover and this morning we include a walking tour of some of the major sights such as the tomb of Hang Kasturi, one of Malacca's five great 15th-century warriors, and Cheng Hoon Teng Temple the oldest Chinese temple in Malaysia. We continue on to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia's capital, where we should arrive in the late afternoon. East and West rub shoulders in this eclectic and energetic city. KL (as it is known locally) has a hugely varied population, comprising mainly of Malays, Sikhs, Chinese, Indians, Tamils (many in local dress), and the odd splash of saffron from a robed Buddhist monk, adding colour to the vibrant street scenes.

dayInfo.title: Visit Batu Caves and discover Kuala Lumpur's varied sights on a walking tour of the city
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we head out of the city and onto the iconic Batu Caves. Some 272 steps lead up to the sacred Hindu temple that lies inside the cave, and wonderful views of the city and beyond can be had from the entrance. The temple is a shrine to a Hindu deity, Lord Murugah and the complex consists of three caves full of colourful Hindu murals and artwork. After time to explore, and witness a puja if we are lucky (a Hindu ceremony of worship where often an offering to the gods or deity will be made), we pay a visit to a well-established Malaysian batik and handicraft manufacturer. Malaysian batik is a traditional wax-resist textile art featuring vibrant floral and nature-inspired designs, reflecting the nation's cultural heritage. Here we learn about the batik-making process and see some of other handicrafts like woodcarvings, pottery, and weaving alongside the batik displays. Finally, we embark on a walking tour of Kuala Lumpur to uncover some of the cultural diversity of this lively and modern city. The tour starts at the colourfully decorated Guan Yin Temple, an ornate Buddhist temple dedicated to Guan Yin, the Goddess of Compassion. We then venture into Chinatown and onto Petaling Street, a pedestrianised lane lined with traditional Chinese lanterns and where anything from sunglasses to Bonsai trees can be bought. We move next to the Hindu temple of Sri Maha Mariamman, a towering temple that is South Indian in style and is said to be the oldest Hindu temple in all of Malaysia. On our way out of Chinatown, we stop via the Central Market before crossing the Gombak River and onto the city's birthplace. This area offers a stark contrast from Chinatown and is full of historic buildings such as the Cathedral of Saint Mary and the Tudor-styled Royal Selangor Club, from Malaysia's colonial days. The rest of the day is free at leisure. If you would prefer to explore, you may wish to visit 'KLCC', the area in which the magnificent Petronas Towers lie. For wonderful views of the Towers along with a choice of Asian-inspired cocktails, head for the 'Sky Bar', residing on the 33rd floor of the Traders Hotel, directly opposite the towers.

dayInfo.title: Drive to the Cameron Highlands. Visit a tea plantation and go on a tea tasting
dayInfo.description: : Waving goodbye to Kuala Lumpur, we set off for the Cameron Highlands, Malaysia's hill country. The highlands were discovered in the heyday of the colonial era, with Victorian explorers sending home news of verdant slopes and mild climes which offered respite to Malaysia's punishing summer swelter. The British soon moved in, and up popped country estate houses, vast swathes of lush tea plantations and curious traditions of tea, scones and strawberries. Present-day Cameron Highlands still retains some of this nostalgic charm, and tea plantations still make up large parts of the landscape. This is a very popular destination with tourists and locals alike, who gather at the one tea centre in the area to enjoy the stunning views of the vast tea plantation beneath. We reach the town of Tanah Rata and from here we travel by 4WD to BOH tea factory. Nestled within many hectares of lush tea plantations, BOH has been growing tea for nearly 100 years. We will take a walk through the rows of plantations to see how tea is grown, picked and harvested, before visiting the factory to learn how it is refined to create the different varieties we find in our brews. Finally, we have a tea tasting to sample some of their best produce. Later in the afternoon we check-in at our hotel. Dinner tonight serves up a contrast to all of this British influence, as we will be cooking our own Malaysian hot pot. A hearty meal often eaten during winter months, this traditional way of cooking allows for meat and fish to be fried, and vegetables and other ingredients to be boiled all together in one pot under an open flame. Overall driving time: approx. 3.5 hours.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Ipoh then head north to Chenderoh Lake; afternoon walk through rural countryside
dayInfo.description: : We drive to Ipoh first thing in the morning - a charming old town, with colonial architecture, rich food culture, and relaxed heritage atmosphere. After a short visit we keep driving to Kuala Kangsar, Perak region's royal town since the late 19th century, is home to Istana Kenangan, the former royal palace built in 1926 entirely of timber without nails. The town also showcases traditional village life, historic mosques, and a peaceful riverside setting steeped in centuries of Malay heritage. In the afternoon, we stop at Ubudiah Royal Mosque and Istana Kenangan, the Perak Royal Museum for photo stops and for a brief time to take in their impressive architecture. We then pay a visit to a celebrated keris maker in Kuala Kangsar, continuing a family tradition passed down through four generations. We see how he forges traditional Malay daggers using ancient techniques, crafts hilts and blades commissioned by royalty, and shares his knowledge through demonstrations to help preserve this unique cultural heritage. Afterwards, we keep heading north and we expect to make it to our homestay in Chenderoh Lake by late afternoon. The Suka Suka Lake Retreat is set on the banks of Chenderoh Lake and offers a great insight into daily life in rural Malaysia. It is set amongst tropical forests and working rubber plantations, and its accommodation comprises a selection of traditional 'Kampung' style guesthouses with en-suite bathrooms and hot showers. Fans and mosquito nets are provided in all of the rooms. After settling into our homestay we set off for an orientation walk around the local area. This area is home to many different plantations, and we will walk through active rubber and palm oil plantations to learn about how these crops are harvested, and why locals have chosen to make a living this way. We hope it offers a unique insight at a grassroots level into the realities of the oil palm trade, a multi-billion dollar industry for which Malaysia is the second-largest exporter in the world. Dinner tonight is likely to be a selection of local fried fish, nasi goreng (tasty fried rice often served with egg and spices) and steamed vegetables. Sambal is another staple at dinner time - a kind of garnish paste made with chillies, herbs and spices. After dinner, there is a chance to try your hand at Congkak - a popular Malaysian board game played with stones or beans. Overall driving time: approx. 3.5 hours.

dayInfo.title: Late morning drive to Penang and orientation tour of eclectic George Town
dayInfo.description: : Part of this morning has been left free to relax in our natural surroundings. There is the option to take a kayak and have a gentle paddle around the calm waters of Chenderoh Lake or perhaps take another short walk. Mid-morning we drive to Penang, our base for the next two nights. Often called the 'Pearl of the Orient' by the local people, Penang lies some 4km off the Malay mainland. Its deep-water harbour is ideal for trade and so the island has become a haven of commerce. After lunch, we visit George Town, Penang capital city, founded in 1786, where colonial buildings and historic landmarks reflect its trading port history. This vibrant city celebrates multicultural heritage, with Chinese, Malay, Indian, and Eurasian influences visible in temples, shophouses, and festivals. Today, George Town thrives with colourful street art, lively markets, and delicious street food, blending tradition with modern city life. In the evening we will organise to eat at one of the many local food stalls that Penang is so famous for, whether Indian, Chinese or Malay, the choice is yours!

dayInfo.title: Visit to a hill-top temple. Free afternoon for further exploration
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we visit the largest Buddhist temple in the region. We visit the majestic Kek Lok Si Temple on a hill, enjoying panoramic views and passing through traditional villages along the way. There is an option to ride on the funicular railway to the top of Penang Hill for far-reaching views across the island. In the afternoon you are free to explore at your own pace. The Botanical Gardens are beautiful and can be reached quite easily by local bus, and there are many other interesting mosques and Buddhist temples to see. Appreciators of art should search out the local batik work at the Penang Art Gallery.

dayInfo.title: Morning ferry to Langkawi island, free afternoon
dayInfo.description: : We rise early this morning for our hour-and-a-half drive to Kuala Kedah and then take a ferry to the idyllic island paradise of Langkawi, a journey of approximately three hours. Langkawi is an archipelago made up of 99 islands lying just off the west coast of the Malaysian Peninsular. Surrounded by turquoise waters, the interior of the main island is a mixture of jungle-clad hills and picturesque paddy fields. This lush interior is encapsulated by white-sand beaches lapped by the warm waters of the Andaman Sea; an ideal place to relax or explore for our last few days in Malaysia. We will be met on arrival on the island and transferred to our base for the next two nights, where the rest of the day is left free at leisure.

dayInfo.title: Free time in Langkawi - relax or optional island hopping
dayInfo.description: : Today is a free day where you can choose to relax on the beautiful coconut palm-fringed beaches or perhaps snorkel amongst the tropical fish of the Andaman Sea. If you would prefer to remain more active, there are several optional excursions which can be arranged. Optional excursions include an island-hopping cruise where you can discover some of the lesser-visited islands of the archipelago, or a visit to the Northern Mangroves taking in the unique geology, flora and fauna of this area. If you want to extend your stay in Langkawi, please contact us to book additional nights.

dayInfo.title: Trip ends in Langkawi
dayInfo.description: : Our trip ends after breakfast at our hotel in Langkawi. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to depart from Langkawi at any time. If your flight is departing later in the day, luggage storage facilities are available at our hotel. If you'd like an airport transfer today, you'll need to depart from Langkawi International Airport (LGK), which is a 30-minute drive from the hotel. If your flight departs in the evening, please contact us before travel to arrange late check-out.

dayInfo.description: Kuala Lumpur: Selamat Datang – welcome to Malaysia! Your family adventure kicks off in Kuala Lumpur, a vibrant city bursting with cultural diversity, colourful neighbourhoods, and irresistible cuisine. Once you’ve checked into your hotel, the afternoon is yours to relax, shake off the jet lag, or head out for a wander and start soaking up the city’s atmosphere. At 5:00 PM, you’ll meet your Adventure Leader and fellow travellers for a welcome briefing. This is where you’ll run through key safety tips, learn more about the journey ahead, and get a feel for the exciting days to come. Then it’s time for the best kind of introduction – your first group dinner! Over plates of delicious Malaysian dishes, you’ll have the chance to get to know your travel companions. Think juicy satay skewers with rich peanut sauce, fragrant coconut rice, and spicy sambal – the perfect first taste of Malaysia’s incredible food culture.

Kuala Lumpur to Sepilok: After breakfast at the hotel, we’ll swap the buzz of the city for the wild beauty of Borneo’s jungles. A quick transfer to the airport takes us to our flight bound for Sandakan – the gateway to lush rainforest and a whole new side of Malaysia. Upon landing, we’ll head to Sepilok and check in to your resort, nestled right beside a protected forest reserve. Surrounded by endless greenery, it’s the perfect place for the whole family to unwind and connect with nature. Cool off in the pool with a backdrop of rainforest views (swimsuits essential!), or take a leisurely stroll along the resort’s 1,500-foot boardwalk that weaves through the treetops. As the day winds down, we’ll head to the Flying Squirrel Platform for an unforgettable sight – with a bit of luck, you might catch these incredible creatures leaping and gliding between the trees at sunset. After dinner, grab your flashlight and join your guide for a nighttime nature walk. This is when the forest truly comes alive – keep your eyes peeled for tarsiers, civets, and even the shy slow loris. It’s the perfect first taste of Borneo’s after-dark magic and a memory your family will treasure.

Sepilok to Kinabatangan: Rise and shine – today is all about adventure and wildlife! We’ll start with a visit to the famous Sepilok Orangutan Rehabilitation Centre, where you can watch these incredible primates swing through the treetops, climb ropes, and enjoy their fruit during feeding time. From there, we’ll make our way to the Bornean Sun Bear Conservation Centre to meet the world’s smallest bear. They may be little, but they’ve got huge personalities. You’ll also learn about the amazing conservation work being done to protect them. Next, we’ll head to Sim Sim Jetty and board a boat for a scenic journey through mangrove-lined waterways towards your hotel in Kinabatangan. Keep your camera handy – the ride is a treat in itself. After lunch and check-in, it’s time for a wildlife cruise along the Kinabatangan River, one of the best spots in Borneo for animal sightings. Look out for playful monkeys, colourful hornbills, and if you’re lucky, maybe even a crocodile lurking by the banks. As night falls, we’ll take to the river again for a magical firefly cruise, watching the trees sparkle like fairy lights. After dinner, grab your torch for a guided night walk along the boardwalk – the perfect chance to spot the jungle’s fascinating nocturnal residents.

Kinabatangan: We’ll start the day with a serene boat ride to Pitas Oxbow Lake, gliding over calm waters as the jungle slowly stirs to life around you. Out on the platform, you’ll be treated to a hearty jungle-style breakfast – a truly unforgettable way to greet the morning. Afterwards, we’ll make our way to Abai Village for a glimpse into local life. You’ll meet some of the warm and welcoming residents and be invited into a villager’s home to enjoy an authentic, home-cooked lunch – a real taste of Bornean hospitality. In the afternoon, we’re back on the river for another wildlife cruise. Every trip brings new surprises, so keep your eyes open for anything from proboscis monkeys to rare bird species along the banks. We’ll return to the lodge in the evening for a relaxed dinner surrounded by the sounds of the jungle.

Kinabatangan to Kuala Lumpur: It’s your last morning in the rainforest – but we’ve saved one final treat. We’ll head out for an early cruise to the Oxbow Lake, soaking up the peaceful sights and sounds of the jungle as the day begins. After enjoying breakfast out on the platform, it’s time to bid farewell to Kinabatangan and make our way by boat back to Sandakan. Before we head to the airport, we’ll gather for a final lunch, sharing stories and favourite moments from our time in Borneo’s wild heart. From there, we’ll catch our flight back to Kuala Lumpur. On arrival, you’ll be transferred to your hotel in the city, with the evening free to relax, recharge, and get ready for the next exciting chapter of your Malaysian journey.

Kuala Lumpur to Cameron Highlands: After breakfast, we’ll check out and set off to explore some of Kuala Lumpur’s most iconic landmarks. Our first stop is a quick but unmissable photo opportunity at the legendary Petronas Twin Towers – the tallest twin towers in the world and a must-have shot for the family album. From there, we’ll visit the impressive National Mosque, a striking example of modern Islamic architecture, before making our way to the vibrant Batu Caves. With its towering golden statue, rainbow-coloured steps, and awe-inspiring limestone caverns, this is one of Malaysia’s most unforgettable temples. In the afternoon, it’s time to swap city buzz for cool, misty hills as we begin our scenic drive to the Cameron Highlands. Winding through lush countryside, you’ll see rolling hills and endless greenery before arriving at our destination. Once we check in, you can settle into the peaceful charm of Malaysia’s tea country.

Cameron Highlands: Today we trade city skylines for rolling hills, cool mountain air, and lush forest trails. After breakfast, we’ll hop into a jeep and set off to explore the Cameron Highlands in style. Our first stop is the famous BOH Tea Plantation – the largest in Malaysia and an absolute icon of the region. You’ll enjoy panoramic views of vibrant green tea fields stretching as far as the eye can see, discover how the Highlands’ most famous export is produced, and soak up the crisp, refreshing air. Next, we venture into the enchanting Mossy Forest. With its gnarled trees, draping moss, and misty atmosphere, it feels like stepping into a storybook. Keep your camera handy – this is one of the Highlands’ most magical spots. We’ll also visit Kea Farm, a lively local market, before heading to Sky Farm in Bertam Valley. Here, the whole family can get hands-on with planting and harvesting vegetables, and learn about hydroponic farming in a fun, interactive way. By late afternoon, we return to the hotel, where the evening is yours to relax, wander the town, or tuck into some of the Highlands’ tasty local dishes.

Cameron Highlands to Ipoh: This morning, we bid farewell to the cool highlands and journey down to Ipoh – a vibrant city bursting with history, colour, and a foodie reputation that’s second to none. Once we arrive, it’s time to stretch your legs and grab a bite! Ipoh is famous for its culinary delights, so whether you go for silky smooth chicken rice, fragrant curry noodles, or those irresistible flaky egg tarts, your taste buds are in for a treat. In the afternoon, we kick off our sightseeing with a visit to Kek Lok Si Cave Temple – an awe-inspiring sanctuary where statues are carved directly into the limestone. It’s one of Southeast Asia’s largest cave temples, blending Mahayana Buddhist influences with traditional Chinese rituals. From there, we wander down the famous Concubine Lane, a charming alley packed with quirky shops and local crafts, before exploring Ipoh’s mural street, where striking street art brings the city’s heritage and culture to life. We’ll round off the day with a bit of local food hunting, then check into our hotel. The evening is yours – whether you want to unwind or head back out to uncover more of Ipoh’s charm.

Ipoh to Penang: After breakfast, it’s time to set off for the next chapter of your Malaysian adventure – Penang! Known for its rich blend of cultures, fascinating history, and world-famous food scene, this island gem is just a relaxed 2-hour drive away. We’ll kick things off with a visit to Kek Lok Si Temple, one of Southeast Asia’s most impressive religious sites. Perched on a hillside, it’s a stunning mix of Chinese, Thai, and Burmese architectural styles, complete with towering pagodas and vibrant prayer halls. You’ll even ride the inclined lift to the upper levels for panoramic views and a closer look at the temple’s intricate details. Next up, we make our way to Penang Hill. Hop aboard the funicular train for a scenic ride to the summit, where sweeping views stretch across George Town, the coastline, and lush green hills. By late afternoon, we’ll check in to the hotel, and the rest of the day is yours to wander Penang’s charming streets, hunt down your first taste of its legendary street food, or simply relax and soak up the island vibes.

Penang: Start your day with a hearty breakfast – you’re about to dive into a morning packed with culture, colour, and fascinating finds! Penang may be small, but it’s a melting pot of traditions, and today you’ll see just how much variety is packed into this vibrant island. Our first stop is the Dhammikarama Burmese Temple, a serene space adorned with ornate carvings, gilded accents, and intricate statues. Just across the road, we’ll visit Wat Chayamangkalaram, home to one of the world’s largest reclining Buddhas – an awe-inspiring 33 metres from head to toe. From there, we head into the heart of George Town to stroll down Armenian Street, where vivid street art brings local stories to life. Next, we’ll make our way to Chew Jetty, a historic stilted village that’s been home to waterfront communities for over a century. Finally, we’ll wrap up with a sensory explosion in Little India, where the air is filled with spice-laden aromas, Bollywood tunes, and bursts of vibrant colour. By early afternoon, we’ll return to the hotel. The rest of the day is yours – whether that means relaxing, sampling more Penang street food, or squeezing in one last wander through the city’s charming lanes.

Penang to Singapore: This morning, we wave goodbye to Malaysia and catch a flight to Singapore! On arrival, we hop on the MRT and head to the hotel to drop off your bags and get settled in. In the evening, it’s straight into the action with dinner at the famous Lau Pa Sat hawker centre. Think unlimited, sizzling satay, local favourites and plenty of great vibes. Afterwards, your Adventure Leader will take you on a walking tour through some of the city’s highlights, including Marina Bay, the Civic District and Merlion Park. You’ll end the night mesmerised with a double light show experience – Spectra over the bay and the Garden Rhapsody beneath glowing trees. It’s truly an incredible experience!

Singapore: Today marks the end of your adventure, but if you’re not quite ready to say goodbye, there is one last optional experience to enjoy. Join a walking tour* through three of Singapore’s most iconic cultural neighbourhoods: Chinatown, Little India and Kampong Gelam. Take in the sights, sounds and stories of each district, get local tips from your guide, and snap some final photos to remember the trip by. If you’re heading home or continuing your travels, we hope you leave with new friends and unforgettable memories as a family! *This is a join-in walking tour, meaning that you’ll be joining other travellers who are also exploring the city! Reach out to our team to find out more and get it booked!

generalInfo:
This unforgettable 2-week Malaysia family tour covers all the bases from culture, history and contemporary streetlife in the fascinating capital Kuala Lumpur and World Heritage George Town through the exotic jungle flora and fauna in Belum Rainforest to the turquoise seas and vibrant coral reefs of the unspoilt Perhentian Islands.

A wide range of activities goes from a street food tour in KL, exploring cave temples and the unique Kellie’s Castle in Ipoh, nature hikes through the lush forest of Penang Hill, searching for giant Rafflesia in Belum’s 130 million-year-old eco-system and snorkelling with baby sharks and giant turtles on reefs in the Gulf of Thailand.

Other highlights include a local train ride up the Peninsula, travelling on Penang Hill’s old 1920s funicular railway, a visit to the spectacular Batu Caves, a boat tour around picturesque Lake Temenggor and checking out the local markets, vibrant Chinatown and famed Little India of Penang.

We’ll also ensure a leisurely pace with plenty of time for older family members to chill-out with a well-placed sundowner and kids to splash around in the pool. We’re offering this Malaysia family tour as a private trip for a minimum of 4 persons so precise itinerary details and activities are flexible and can, to a large extent, be discussed with your guide and played by ear.

Our Coast to Coast itinerary is a former winner of the Malaysia Tourism, 'best-escorted tour to Malaysia travel award.

Note that this family holiday is designed for the March to September period while from October to February we would, for weather reasons, swap our island stay from the Perhentians to Langkawi.

Features:

1. Discover vibrant KL; the street-life of Chinatown, classic Victorian architecture & the iconic Petronas Towers
2. Explore UNESCO World Heritage Penang with its British architecture, Little India and well-preserved Chinatown
3. Visit some of the unusual sights of off the beaten track Ipoh; street art, cave temples and Kellie's Castle
4. Head into the interior with an expedition into the vast, still largely pristine, yet little visited, jungle of Belum
5. 3-day stay on the fabulous Perhentian Islands; jungle clad and surrounded by white sands and turquoise waters
6. ...and of course meet the super friendly locals and sample one of Asia's most outstanding and varied cuisines

Optional extensions

1. Bangkok tour; explore some of the iconic sites hidden backstreets and local markets of this sprawling, sometime chaotic but ever fascinating Asian metropolis
2. Add on a 4-day, off the beaten track mini-tour of Behind the Scenes Bangkok
3. A 4-day family-friendly exploration of some of the varied and fascinating sites of Thailand's historic Kanchanaburi Province

dayInfo.description: Arrival in KL and check-in to our comfortable downtown hotel with the afternoon to relax, recover from your jet-lag or explore the area’s lively markets before a late afternoon introductory walking tour and a local-style welcome dinner.

Leaving the city centre we’ll travel by train to the northern edge of KL and the famous and highly revered Batu Caves. From here we return to the historic centre for a walking tour taking in the old central mosque and the fabulous Victorian-era architecture of Merdeka Square. An evening walking tour of Kampung Baru introduces you to some of the array of local street food on offer as well as providing some spectacular views of the city’s iconic Petronas Towers.

Morning ride by local train to Ipoh. Originally founded on the back of its 19th-century tin mining industry today the town is renowned for its cuisine, rich architectural heritage and, unusually, its spectacular street art! The region is also famous for caves and after time for a wander, we’ll head out to Sam Poh Tong – one of the most spectacular and picturesque cave temple sites.

Walking tour to check out some of the fantastic street art as well as the town’s well-preserved Chinese architecture and impressive stock of colonial-period buildings. In the afternoon we’ll head out what is perhaps Ipoh’s most iconic site – Kellie’s Castle. Begun a century ago by a Scottish plantation owner, he died before work could be completed and is today thought by locals to haunt the corridors and towers of his unfinished gothic folly.

Morning road transfer to Penang Island and check in to our heritage-style hotel in George Town’s historic, downtown jetty quarter with the afternoon free to explore the area or maybe check out one of the famous hawker, street-food markets?

Penang’s capital George Town reveals a bewildering mix of Malay, Indian and Chinese cultures; Buddhist, Christian, Muslim and Hindu religions. Our walking tour of this well-preserved town takes in exotic temples, Chinese architecture, colourful Little India and impressive British colonial-period buildings. The afternoon is free to explore the fascinating and friendly town at your leisure, check out the local markets or museums while an optional visit to the historic Cheong Fatt Tse ‘blue mansion’ can be arranged

Lush, forest-covered and colonial villa-topped Penang Hill towers over the island so today’s visit entails taking the old funicular railway up, and hiking down through the rainforest, to the Botanical Gardens. Great views and tropical flora and fauna. An evening street food tour completes the day.

Time to leave Penang and head off into the rarely visited interior of the Peninsula through the jungle-clad hills to tranquil Banding Island in Temenggor Lake. Accommodation at a beautifully situated lakeside eco-resort.

Day expedition into the surrounding Belum Forest – West Malaysia’s largest preserved forest area – including a boat trip on the scenic lake, a waterfall visit and a jungle hike to a salt lick as well as searching for the rare and spectacular Rafflesia flower. With luck, we’ll see monkeys, giant hornbills and maybe even elephants – spectacular scenery guaranteed!

Transfer to Kuala Besut port on the Peninsula’s east coast, and on by speedboat to the jungle-clad and coral-fringed paradise of the Perhentian Islands. Tourism is still relatively undeveloped in these islands and we’ll be staying in a low-key but comfortable beach-side resort.

A day at leisure or exploring the island? Options include a hike into the well-preserved jungle interior to search for the prehistoric-looking giant monitor lizards that roam the islands – plus leaf monkeys, colourful birdlife or walks to some of the more remote bays and creeks.

At leisure on the islands or take a snorkelling tour of some of the vibrant coral reefs that surround the island. Fantastic turquoise waters, myriad colourful fish and encounters with baby reef sharks and giant turtles!
Transfer by speedboat and taxi to nearby Kota Bharu for a return flight to Kuala Lumpur.

placesVisited: Kuala Lumpur, Taman Negara National Park, Cameron Highlands, Penang, Langkawi
generalInfo:
Kuala Lumpur - Taman Negara National Park - Cameron Highlands - Penang - Langkawi

This itinerary in magical Malaysia offers a blissful blend of vibrant cities, luscious tea hills, rainforests, waterways and stunning beaches- all in the space of just two weeks. If you want a well rounded taste of Malaysia that is perfectly balanced between adventure and relaxation, you've come to the right place.

Beginning in Kuala Lumpur, jump straight into the cacophony of street markets, and famous tourist spots like the Petronas Towers, Chinatown, Little India and Merdeka Square. The best way to shake that jet lag is to just get out there and experience it all!

After your introduction to the crazy capital city, it's time to head to higher climbs in Taman Negara national park. Enjoy an epic canopy walk through the forest for a birds eye view of the flora and fauna, before your night safari from the perspective of the water. This is the world's oldest tropical rainforest, so it should definitely be on your bucket list if it isn't already!

From jungle to butterfly gardens to tea plantations: Your next stop is the much famed and incredibly beautiful Cameron highlands where you can enjoy the perfect cup of tea in these unparalleled, lush surroundings. Kick back in the crisp fresh air and visit a local strawberry farm for a true taste of rural Malay life.

From tea production to even more cultural fusion, your next stop is the island of Penang, many adventurer's all time favourite destination in Malaysia. This incredible place is a beautiful blend of Chinese, Indian and Malaysian influences, creating some of the best food, artwork, and towns of the region. Enjoy a leisurely bike ride through Georgetown to really get to grips with the cultural heart of Malaysia.

After all that travelling, it's time for a well earned rest. Just a three hour transfer away lie the blissful beaches of lovely Langkawi. If you still have the energy for further exploration, this gorgeous coast is home to many waterfalls and small kampungs (local villages). Otherwise, feel the white sand between your toes and swim in the turquoise ocean for the ultimate does of R&R. If you haven't decided what time of year to travel yet, ask our specialists about turtle season.

After the ultimate tropical paradise get away it's time to make your way home- and sift through all those holiday snaps!

dayInfo.description: Twin Towers & Chopsticks: Kuala Lumpur is a city of exciting extremes, where space-age skyscrapers nudge up against cluttered Chinese markets and timeless Indian restaurants. You’ll explore Kuala Lumpur independently, watching East bump into West with your own eyes. You can stare up at the famous Petronas Towers, throw yourself into lively food-court culture and get a bird’s eye view from the top of the KL Tower.

Canopy Walk and Jungle Boat: Get a bus and a boat over to the natural paradise of Taman Negara. Here, you’ll trek through the treetops, take a boat trip past jungle-flanked riverbanks and try a wildlife-spotting night safari during this tranquil adventure through Malaysia’s most famous National Park. You’ll explore the world’s oldest tropical rainforest, and make sure you keep your eyes peeled for all the wildlife. By night, you’ll stay in a wooden bungalow in the jungle.

Time for Tea: After breakfast it’s time to bid farewell to the jungle and cross the river where you’ll find your mini-bus waiting to take you to the Cameron Highlands, which should take roughly 5.5 hours. Time for Tea: After breakfast it’s time to bid farewell to the jungle and cross the river where you’ll find your mini-bus waiting to take you to the Cameron Highlands. Amble through the rolling tea plantations a picturesque sight of a sea of green. Breathe in the cool air and stop off for steaming mugs of freshly brewed tea. You’ll learn about the local art of tea production at Malaysia’s premier tea estate. En route, you’ll stop at butterfly gardens and strawberry farms, giving you a taste of highland life in Malaysia.

Bites and Bikes of Penang: Next, you’ll take an early morning bus to the cultural island of Penang. This Malaysian state is a patchwork of Chinese, Indian and Malay cultures, there’s always something fascinating happening on every street corner. The food here is famous throughout the world, a mouth-watering hotchpotch of Asian flavours that will get your taste buds dancing. During this trip you’ll take a bike ride around the UNESCO World Heritage site of Georgetown, the cultural heart of Penang and sample some tasty traditional cuisine.

Lazing Around on Langkawi: Next, you’ll be collected from your hotel in Penang for your trip north to Kuala Kedah, breaking up the journey to board the ferry to Langkawi. A cocktail of coconut palms, calm turquoise waters and soft white sand, Langkawi is a classic tropical paradise. It’s somewhere to stretch out in the sunshine, snorkel through coral reefs and sip coconut juice. While the secret about Langkawi is definitely out, the island has managed to keep plenty of colourful local character. Take the cable car up to the top of Gunung Machincang, search for hidden waterfalls or explore the traditional kampungs. Today your holiday to Malaysia comes to an end. Your arranged driver will take you to Langkawi Airport for your onwards flight to Kuala Lumpur, and then an international flight home to the UK.

tourName: Malaysia holiday, Kuala Lumpur & Tioman Island
placesVisited: Kuala Lumpur, Villa Samadhi, day to explore the capital, visit the Forest Research Institute of Malaysia, Tioman Island, Japamala boutique resort, beaches, reefs and jungle, optional: snorkelling, scuba diving, hiking, village visits
generalInfo:
A wonderful 13 day break, this Malaysia holiday, to Kuala Lumpur and Tioman Island, combines the capital’s exciting architecture, thriving foodie scene and busy markets with a relaxing week on beautiful Tioman Island, off the east coast of the peninsula.

Kuala Lumpur became Malaysia’s capital in 1890, and the colonial buildings of Merdeka Square contrasts with the bold contemporary architecture found here, including the world famous Petronas Towers, the tallest building in the world. Home to three main cultures – Malay, Indian and Chinese – the city is diverse, with a Chinatown, Little India, mosques, temples and slick shopping malls. Here, stay in a beautiful villa style hotel on the edge of the city, in the quiet embassy district away from the hustle and bustle. Take a day to explore beyond the city, too, with a visit to the Forest Research Institute of Malaysia, where you can enjoy exploring and learning about the jungle.

After three nights in KL, you’ll travel to remote and delightful Tioman Island. This is a classically beautiful ‘paradise’ island, complete with blue seas and white sand beaches backed by jungle. The waters around the island have been declared a marine reserve and much of the jungle inland is protected as a wildlife reserve. Relax and enjoy the peace, or try scuba diving and snorkelling to inspect the coral reefs. You might also like to hike around the island, to spot some of the 45 species of mammal that live here. Visit a few of the eight villages, too, to see local life and chat with the islanders, too.

You will spend seven nights here in the stylishly rustic Japamala boutique resort, which has just 13 villas and chalets. It’s tucked away in the jungle and close to a beach with an offshore reef – a private and comfortable place with friendly service, where you can relax surrounded by nature. There are lovely restaurants – one sitting at the tip of a jetty – and an excellent spa.

Enjoy exploring Tioman Island today.
Days at leisure to relax at the resort.

Early morning arrival into the UK

tourName: Malaysia holiday, Kuala Lumpur to Penang
generalInfo:
On our 8-day Malaysia World Heritage tour you'll discover some of the highlights of the Malay Peninsula; its rich cultural and historical heritage, magnificent landscapes and flora and fauna as well as the vibrant contemporary street-life and, of course, fabulous cuisine.

The strategically located Malay Peninsula has been the hub of maritime trade between China and India for over 2,000 years and today shows ancient Buddhist and Hindu vestiges as well as displaying more recent Portuguese, Dutch and British influences creating exceptionally rich architectural and historical traditions.

With the influx of Tamil, Sikh and Bengalis during British rule and the unique Straights Chinese culture, Malaysia’s contemporary mix is every bit as complex and the resulting cuisine certainly justifies its ‘best of Asia’ tag.

We’ll show you the bewildering variety Kuala Lumpur has to offer from the iconic Petronas Towers to its magnificent Victorian vestiges and colourful Little India as well as the beautifully-preserved Chinatowns, clan mansions, outlying villages and vibrant street markets of World Heritage Malacca and Penang.

You’ll also take in the spectacular Batu Caves, go on a boat trip along the Malacca River, ride the venerable old funicular railway up Penang Hill and hike back down through lush rainforest and even join a hands-on Malaysian cookery class in a tropical spice garden.

An enthralling and varied introduction to what is still a surprisingly little-known part of Southeast Asia.

Features:

1. Combine the historic Dutch, Portuguese and British heritage with contemporary Indian, Chinese and Malay culture
2. Discover the contrasting sights of the vibrant capital Kuala Lumpur from the highly traditional to ultra-modern
3. Explore the twin UNESCO World Heritage-listed sites of Melaka (Malacca) and George Town (Penang)
4. Varied activities include a jungle hike on Penang Island, a hands-on Malay cookery class and rickshaw tour of Malacca
5. Optional beach extensions to the Andaman Sea's Langkawi Island or the Perhentians Islands on the Gulf of Thailand
6. ...and last but not least - certainly some of the best and most varied food to be found anywhere in Asia

Optional extensions

1. Take a ferry from Penang to lush tropical Langkawi Island
2. A domestic flight and speedboat ride will see you on the unspoilt, coral-fringed Perhentian Islands (April to Sept)

Note groups sizes are min 4 to max 12 persons with most meals (local-style) included and accommodation in 3 to 4* hotels.

dayInfo.description: Our tour begins with a transfer from Kuala Lumpur International Airport to our downtown hotel (or rendezvous in the lobby for those booking a land only tour) and some time to settle in and relax before an introductory walking tour and local-style welcome dinner.

From here we return to the historic centre for a walking tour taking in the old central mosque and the fabulous Victorian-era architecture of Merdeka Square. An evening walking tour of Kampung Baru introduces you to some of the array of local street food on offer as well as providing some spectacular views of the city’s iconic Petronas Towers.

Morning departure for the coast and Melaka (Malacca) with an afternoon orientation tour by rickshaw of the historic, UNESCO-listed city. The UNESCO World Heritage-listed town displays Portuguese, Dutch and British influences and we’ll allow you time in the late afternoon and evening to explore at your leisure.

Return to Kuala Lumpur to catch the Butterworth express train to northern Malaysia. Late afternoon arrival and transfer by ferry to our heritage-style hotel in George Town's historic, downtown jetty quarter with the evening free to explore the area or maybe check out one of the famous hawker street-food markets.

An ascent of Penang Hill by the famous jungle, funicular jungle railway – originally dating back to the Victorian era - for some spectacular views across the island and a visit to the Habitat Park to check-out their canopy walkway and ‘tree-tops’ trail. In the afternoon we return down the hill for a short drive to the island’s picturesque Botanical Gardens.

A food-orientated morning with a visit to the island's Tropical Spice Garden. An explanation and tour of the garden's myriad herbs and spices are followed by a hands-on cookery lesson where you'll prepare your own lunch. Short afternoon hike to unspoilt Monkey Beach in nearby Penang National Park.

Morning at leisure and end of the tour. A transfer to Penang International Airport is included for those booking the flights package or, for those with a few more days to spare, we offer the options of island extensions to Langkawi (express boat from Penang) or the Perhentian Islands (domestic flight to Kota Baru and speedboat transfer) or a flight to Kota Kinabalu to link up with our 8-day Borneo, Sabah tour.

placesVisited: Kuala Lumpur, Kuching, Lemanak River, Semenggok Orangutan Sanctuary, Batang Ai, Bako National Park, Kuala Lumpur, Tioman Island, Optional activities include: jungle trekking, boat trips from Tioman Island
generalInfo:
Mainland Malaysia is great, but its islands are even better. On this relaxed two week trip you’ll start in Kuching on Borneo, then head back to the mainland Malaysia for a flying visit to Kuala Lumpur, before seeking well-deserved R&R on Tioman Island, 20 miles off the east coast.

Start your adventure in the city of Kuching, Borneo. Malaysian Borneo, part of the wonderful jungle-bound island, is famous for orang-utans, and you can meet them at Semenggok Orangutan Sancturary, just out Kuching. Explore some of the world’s most beautiful rainforest, and spend time in an Iban community, sharing dinner and staying in a longhouse. Next try and spot the animal with the strangest nose at Bako National Park: hornbills and proboscis monkeys vie for the title.

Head over to mainland Malaysia and stay a night in Kuala Lumpur, the busy capital, where you’ll want to dive straight into the street markets. Transfer on to the east coast, where a boat trip gets you to Tioman Island. This South China Sea ‘pulau’ (island) is set in national park. All across its protected marine reserves, sea fans wave and busy reef fish flourish.

There are great beaches here, and the one you’ll stay on at Japamala is no different. This boutique resort offers boat trips and kayaks for adventurous visitors from its sandy shores. Jungle walkways connect its rustic chalets and villas through the canopy to its restaurants and highly-recommended spa. Or you could just lay out your bamboo mat at the beach and chill out.

dayInfo.description: Today you begin your journey by boarding your international outbound flight to Kuching.

Arriving into Kuching you're met by an Audley representative and transferred by private driver to your hotel. Depending on your flight time, you have the rest of the day to relax- you might like to wander into Kuching this evening to explore many of the local restaurants, cafes and street-food stalls.

Enjoy the day discovering the history and beauty of the riverside city of Kuching on a private walking tour with an experienced guide. On foot, explore the narrow alleyways and markets to see daily unfold - as well as seeing many of the temples and churches the city is known for. With a range of colonial influences from Indian mosques to Chinese temples, your guide can help you understand the complex history of the town.

Leave Kuching this morning and visit the Semenggok Orang-utan Sanctuary in time for the morning feeding session with your private guide. Continue the journey on to Lemanak River to stay the night in a longhouse with the Iban people, descendants of the infamous headhunters. This journey with private guide lasts all day, with stops along the way to explore. Arrive at the longhouse in time to be welcomed for dinner with the family- usually followed by traditional dancing and music.

Your Iban host teaches you how the tribe live off the natural resources of the jungle this morning on a private guided walk. Say goodbye to the tribe as you depart by private longboat, and then car, to a more comfortable hotel for the night. On arrival, check in to your room before enjoying a private guided nature walk with the opportunity to walk along the tree-top canopy walkways of the surrounding forest.

Leave Lemanak River and head back to Kuching today. Leaving from the hotel's jetty, you have a short shared boat transfer before being met by your private driver for the four hour drive to Kuching. Along the way you can stop for a simple local meal.

Spend the day in Bako National Park with your private guide to spot some of Borneo's stunning wildlife such as proboscis monkey, bearded pig and hornbill. An early start, drive by private transfer 40 minutes outside the city before catching a boat for a 30 minute ride across to the park. This tour can be tailored to your interests, with your guide on hand to help you explore many of the waterfalls, streams and jungle paths.

This morning you're collected from your hotel for a private transfer to Kuching airport to catch your short flight to Kuala Lumpur. On arrival in Kuala Lumpur, an Audley representative will meet you and accompany you to your hotel by private transfer. Depending on the time of your flight, you many have time to explore the city a little. A city best explored on foot, you might like to walk to some of the many street-food markets near your hotel to try some local delicacies.
This morning you transfer to the east coast, a journey of several hours but well worth it. Take a shared boat to Tioman Island, where you will have 4 nights to relax at the gorgeous JapaMala.
Today you have the day to enjoy JapaMala. You might like to explore the surrounding waters by booking a private boat excursion to a nearby island or bay, or simply try from the jetty.

Another day today to enjoy your hotel. Private jungle treks can be arranged with the hotel, from longer treks visiting the next village to short walks to a nearby viewpoint- ideal for watching the sunset.

Enjoy your final full day away at leisure at the JapaMala. The spa comes highly recommended. For a special end to your trip, you might like to book at table at Mandi-Mandi, the hotel's small restaurant built on stilts over the water.
Catch a shared boat transfer back to Kuala Lumpur today where you're met and driven to the airport in time for your onwards flight.
Arrive home today to complete your journey.

placesVisited: Kuala Lumpur, Bukit Teresek, walk the world’s longest suspension bridge, Lata Berkoh cascades, Kuala Tembeling, Taman Negara, Langkawi
generalInfo:
A wonderful 12 night tour of Malaysia which takes in the wonders of the 130 million year old Taman Negara rainforest which is one of the world's most complex and rich ecosystems along with the excitement of Kuala Lumpur and the serene beaches of Langkawi.

Kuala Lumpur is an exciting mix of the ultra modern combined with the history and splendour of the temples and mosques and is a fabulous start to any Malaysia trip. Here you can sit side by side with the locals in street-side hawker stalls serving fabulous Malaysian food or explore the high-rise shopping malls for all the must have gadgets. Whilst here you should also fit in a visit to Chinatown, the area that never sleeps, and of course climb the Petronas Towers for a stunning view of the city below.

Taman Negara’s National Park vegetation communities range from the humid tropical rainforest of the lowlands, to the montane oak and ericaceous forests of a higher elevation offering guests the chance to not only view a vast array of flora and fauna but the animals which inhabit the region too. This may include tapirs, wild pigs, tigers, mouse deers and a host of birdlife. The region is in actual fact a birdwatchers paradise, with about 300 species of birdlife recorded in the Park.

Aside from visiting the National Park, you will also spend time on the Island of Langkawi, famous for its beaches and islands being some of the most beautiful in Southeast Asia. Langkawi consists of a group of around 100 islands, and while most are uninhabited, a few allow visitors. Here you will be staying in a hotel with a very impressive legacy of environmental principles actively being followed.

This tour is with an English-speaking guide. The knowledgeable local guides or drivers will accompany you for the duration of your trip or where necessary. This vacation can be tailor-made to create a unique vacation for your individual requirements by travel experts with intimate knowledge of the destination.

dayInfo.description: Depart the UK with Malaysia Airlines and fly non-stop overnight to Kuala Lumpur.
Land in Kuala Lumpur, then transfer into the city for one night. Time at leisure to explore the city for the afternoon. Overnight.

This morning you will depart Kuala Lumpur for Kuala Tembeling and the jetty for the boat crossing to Taman Negara for your rainforest experience. The afternoon is at leisure to relax before dinner and a night jungle walk to see the nocturnal animals. Overnight stay in Mutiara Taman Negara Resort [B/D].

After breakfast you will start the day with a jungle trek to Bukit Teresek with its panoramic views of Gunung (Mount) Tahan and the forest canopy. Walk the canopy walkway, the world’s longest suspension bridge at 1740 feet long, not for the faint hearted at 130 feet above the ground. After returning for lunch you will also enjoy a boat trip to Lata Berkoh cascades to enjoy a spot of swimming in the natural jacuzzi. Overnight stay in Mutiara Taman Negara Resort [B/L/D].

Today you will enjoy breakfast at the Resort and then take the boat and road trip back to Kuala Lumpur. Transfer to the airport and take your short flight across to Langkawi and your hotel for the next 7 nights [B].
Days at leisure to relax and enjoy the Resort [B].

Day at leisure to explore the city.
Transfer back to Kuala Lumpur airport for the flight back to the UK [B].

generalInfo:
Beginning in Malaysia’s fascinating KL we’ll explore the city’s highly eclectic sites from stately Victorian architecture to the iconic Petronas Towers and from the spectacular Batu Caves to the colourful local markets, street-life and of course street-food. From here we move to the Peninsula’s west coast and the twin World Heritage sites of Melaka (Malacca) and George Town (Penang). The former displays its old Portuguese and Dutch heritage while in Penang we’ll visit the Little India quarter and what is perhaps Southeast Asia’s most extensive and best preserved Chinatown as well as the island’s colonial-period British remains.

On our itinerary we’ll take a boat trip along the Malacca River to discover traditional village life, take a ride on Penang Hill’s famous funicular railway before hiking through the Hill’s lush rainforest and join a hands-on Malaysian cookery class in a tropical spice garden.

Heading into the interior we’ll visit the picturesque cave temples (and a haunted Scottish castle no less) around rarely-visited Ipoh and hike through the magnificent landscapes of the old hill station, the Cameron Highlands, before completing our circular tour with a return to KL.

An exciting and varied introduction to this still little-known Southeast Asian country.

Features:

dayInfo.description: Arrival in KL and check-in to our hotel in the heart of the capital’s bustling Chinatown. Afternoon to relax, recover from your jet-lag or explore the area’s lively markets before a late afternoon introductory walking tour and a local-style welcome dinner.

Morning walking tour of some of the highly varied sites of the fascinating Malaysian capital including Little India and the fabulous Victorian-era architecture of Merdeka Square followed by a visit to the famous Batu Caves. An evening walking tour of Kampung Baru introduces you to the fantastic array of local street food on offer.

Early morning departure for the old port of Melaka (former Malacca) with a traditional-style orientation tour by rickshaw. The UNESCO World Heritage-listed town displays Portuguese, Dutch and British influences and we’ll allow you time to explore at your leisure before a late afternoon boat trip up the Malacca River to discover the old Malay district of Morton Village.

Morning return to KL where we’ll catch the train north up the Peninsula to Butterworth. Late afternoon arrival, transfer to Penang Island and check in to our hotel in World Heritage George Town’s historic jetty district. Evening at leisure to perhaps check out the famous hawker street-food market?

Penang’s capital George Town reveals a bewildering mix of Malay, Indian and Chinese cultures; Buddhist, Christian, Muslim and Hindu religions. Our walking tour of this well-preserved town takes in exotic temples, Chinese clan houses, colourful Little India and impressive British colonial-period architecture. The afternoon is free to explore the fascinating and friendly town at your leisure and check out the local markets, museums or vibrant street-life.

An ascent of Penang Hill by the famous jungle, funicular jungle railway – originally dating back to the Victorian era - for some spectacular views across the island and a visit to the Habitat Park to check-out their canopy walkway and ‘tree-tops’ trail. In the afternoon we return down the hill for a short drive to the island’s picturesque Botanical Gardens.

A culinary morning with a visit to the lush Tropical Spice Garden for a guided tour of the bewildering array of local spices and herbs they grow followed by a hands-on Malay cookery lesson. Afternoon at leisure with options of being dropped at Batu Ferringhi for some beach time or a hike to unspoilt Pantai Aceh in nearby Penang National Park.

Morning drive to Ipoh. Originally founded on the back of its 19th-century tin mining industry today the town is renowned for its cuisine, its rich architectural heritage and, unusually, its spectacular street art! The region is also famous for caves and after time for a wander, we’ll head out to Sam Poh Tong – one of the most spectacular and picturesque temple sites.

Walking tour to check out some of the street art as well as the town’s well-preserved Chinese architecture and impressive stock of colonial-period buildings. In the afternoon we’ll head out what is perhaps Ipoh’s most iconic site – Kellie’s Castle. Begun a century ago by a Scottish plantation owner, he died before work could be completed and is today thought by locals to haunt the corridors and towers of his unfinished Gothic folly.

Leaving Ipoh, our first stop will be the impressive limestone cave system of Tempurung. From here we continue onwards and upwards to today’s destination, the former hill station of the Cameron Highlands. Late afternoon orientation tour of the town followed by a chance to sample the town’s culinary speciality - a ‘steamboat’ dinner.

The site was chosen by the British due to its cool mountain climate and today the area is best known for its extensive tea plantations and strawberry farms as well as its rich and varied flora and fauna. Our day’s itinerary follows these threads with a morning forest hike up Coral Hill followed by a tea plantation visit with an optional Malay-style afternoon tea.
Return drive to KL with some time in the afternoon to relax or perhaps do some last-minute souvenir shopping in Chinatown before our evening farewell dinner.

Our tour finishes at check-out time with a transfer at your leisure to Kuala Lumpur International Airport. If you have any days to spare then we can drop you at the domestic terminal for a flight to either Langkawi, (Oct to March) or Kota Bharu for the Perhentian Islands (March to Sept.) for some quality island and beach time.
